explanation:
To determine whether OS_CondVarBroadcast (which itself contains no for loops) can cause a MISRA violation via called code, the analyzer must inspect the implementations of all functions it directly calls and their immediate callees for any for loops and whether those loops are well-formed. Required symbols and reasons:

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Direct callee. Its body must be inspected for any for loops and whether they violate the rule.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById. Include to inspect any loops in its implementation (transitive effect on loop behaviour).
- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById. Include to inspect its loop usage and side effects on loop counters/objects.
- OS_ObjectIdConvertToken: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById. Include for the same reason.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById. Include for the same reason.
- OS_CondVarBroadcast_Impl: Direct callee. Its body must be checked for for loops and any modifications of loop counters by called functions.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Callee of OS_CondVarBroadcast_Impl. Include to examine any loops and side effects that would affect loop correctness.

Additionally the analyzer needs the types/constants used in the call and control flow to fully understand semantics and whether objects used in loop clauses are modified:

- OS_object_token_t: Type of the token variable passed into implementations; needed to understand which objects may be accessed/modified inside called functions (affects whether loop clauses use objects modified in the loop body).
- osal_id_t: Type of var_id parameter; understanding its semantics may be necessary if passed into deeper functions that contain loops.
- OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, OS_SUCCESS: Macro/constant definitions used in the call(s) and return value checks; needed to interpret control flow (e.g., whether certain branches are taken) so the analyzer can determine which functions/loops are actually executed.

Collecting the source code (or bodies) for the listed functions and the definitions of the listed types/macros allows a complete check for any for-loops reachable from OS_CondVarBroadcast and whether those loops meet the MISRA well-formed for-loop requirements (single loop counter, no modifications in body except allowed, second clause has no persistent side effects, etc.).
